InstrumentControl¶

The InstrumentControl object is the primary interface to communicating with instruments. It simplifies script development by abstracting local and remote instruments as simple Python objects.

class InstrumentControl.InstrumentControl(**kwargs)[source]¶
Parameters:Logger (Logging.logger) – Logger instance if you wish to override the internal instance

InstrumentControl is a helper class that provides functionality to communicate with any number of local or remote InstrumentManager instances.

InstrumentControl simplifies the process of writing test instrument automation and control scripts. This is accomplished by abstracting the communication with InstrumentManager instances that contain the device interface code.

Note

InstrumentManager must be running on the local or remote machine that you are trying to connect to. InstrumentControl.startManager() can be used to spawn a new process of InstrumentManager.

addManager(address, port=None)[source]¶

Connect to a manager instance at the given address and port. If the connection is successful, the remote resources are automatically added to the pool of resources using refreshResources()

Parameters:
  • address (str) – IP Address or Hostname
  • port (int) – Port
Returns:

True if manager found, False if connection failed
addResource(address, controller, ResID, VendorID=None, ProductID=None)[source]¶

Create a managed resource within a controller object

If controller is not a valid controller on the remote manager instance, or if the controller does not support manually adding resources, this function will return False.

Note

Controllers that rely on system resources such as VISA or serial can only communicate with devices that are known to the system. Controllers that have no way to scan or enumerate devices depend on this function to make it aware of the device. An example of this is a CAN bus-based Controller, which must know a device address before communication can be established.

Parameters:
  • address (str) – IP Address of manager
  • controller (str) – Name of controller to attach new resource
  • ResID (str) – Resource Identifier
  • VendorID (str) – Vendor Identifier for automatic model loading
  • ProductID (str) – Product Identifier for automatic model loading
Returns:

bool - True if success, False otherwise

Get a list of connected addresses

Returns:list of connected addresses
getConnectedHosts()[source]¶

Get a list of connected hostnames

Returns:List of connected hostnames
getControllers(address)[source]¶

Get a list of controllers from a given InstrumentManager instance.

Parameters:address (str - IPv4) – IP Address
Returns:dict
getHostname(address)[source]¶

Get the Hostname for the given address

Parameters:address (str - IPv4) – IP Address
Returns:str
getInstrument(res_uuid, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a RpcClient instance that is linked to a resource on a local or remote machine.

Parameters:res_uuid (str) – Unique Resource Identifier (UUID)
Returns:RpcClient object or None if UUID does not match a valid resource
getInstrument_driver(d_driver)[source]¶

Get a list of RpcClient objects for resources with the given device driver (Model).

Note

Only resources that have a model loaded will report a device type.

Returns:list of RpcClient objects
getInstrument_list()[source]¶

Get a list of RpcClient objects for all resources with models loaded

Note

This function opens a socket to every known instrument with a Model loaded. This could use a lot of system resources both locally and on remote InstrumentManagers if you don’t need them.

Returns:list of RpcClient objects
getInstrument_model(model_number)[source]¶

Get a list of RpcClient objects for resources with the given model number.

Note

Only resources that have a model loaded will report a model number.

Returns:list of RpcClient objects
getInstrument_serial(serial_number)[source]¶

Get a RpcClient object for the resource with the given serial number.

Note

Only resources that have a model loaded will report a serial number.

Returns:RpcClient object
getInstrument_type(d_type)[source]¶

Get a list of RpcClient objects for resources with the given device type.

Note

Only resources that have a model loaded will report a device type.

Returns:list of RpcClient objects
getManager(address)[source]¶

Get an InstrumentManager object for the host at address. Object returned is an common.rpc.RpcClient object that is linked to a remote InstrumentManager instance.

Note

This will always return an common.rpc.RpcClient object, even if the InstrumentManager instance is on the local machine.

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address of manger
Returns:common.rpc.RpcClient object or None if there is no existing connection to address
getModels(address)[source]¶

Get the list of Models from an InstrumentManager instance

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address of manager
Returns:list
getResources()[source]¶

Get a listing of all resources from all InstrumentManager instances.

Returns:dict (Resource UUID as key)
refreshResources(address=None)[source]¶

Refresh the local resource cache of all connected InstrumentManager instances. If an address is provided, only the specified cache will be refreshed.

Note

Use addManager() to establish a connection to a manager before calling this function.

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address or Hostname
Returns:True unless there is no existing connection to address
removeManager(address)[source]¶

Disconnect from the manager instance at address and purge all cached resources from that host.

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address of manger
Returns:True unless there is no existing connection to address
startManager()[source]¶

Start a local instance of InstrumentManager using subprocess.Popen().

No attempt is made to check whether an InstrumentManager process is already running. The default behavior for :class:’InstrumentManager’ is to exit when the port is already in use.

See :class:’InstrumentManager’ documentation for more information.

Note

This function does not block! If the InstrumentManager instance is not fully initialized before attempting to connect to it, timeouts will occur.

stopManager(address, port=None)[source]¶

Send a stop signal to a manager instance running on a local or remote machine.

Note

InstrumentManager cannot be restarted once it is stopped

Parameters:
  • address (str) – IP Address or Hostname
  • port (int) – Port
Returns:

Nothing
